repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`vim.wait()` cannot be called in a fast callback since the main loop cannot be run in that context as it is not reentrant


Fixes #26122

comment_data.body:
`#` is enough to disambiguate
```suggestion
    it('should not run the main loop in fast callbacks #26122', function()
```
This makes sense to me and is the general direction I hope we can drive towards. Ideally scripts shouldn't have to check `vim.in_fast_event()` or explicitly schedule() things.

In general I think they still have to, it's just that `vim.wait()` was initially designed to be callable in fast callbacks, however there existed a path which caused it to run the main loop and crash.

> In general I think they still have to,

yes, out of scope for this PR, but still something we can aspire to.
This means `vim.wait()` doesn't wait at all in a fast context, which may be confusing.

Hmm, doesn't the doc for the `fast_only` parameter imply that this is already the case? 

Do we need a `fast_loop` where non-editor, Lua-only processing is done? (Or does `NULL` already work like that?)

```
      â€¢ {fast_only}  (boolean|nil) If true, only |api-fast| events will be
                     processed. If called from while in an |api-fast| event,
                     will automatically be set to `true`.
```

One of the main use cases for `vim.wait()` is to for applications like `vim.system()` where we want to uv to poll and check for IO, however this only happens on the main loop.

> Or does NULL already work like that?

NULL just ensures we never run the main loop, but it will still process any outstanding fast/main events. However I think zeer is right and maybe this change is wrong.

I don't see how we can run the uv loop when we are in a fast callback, so maybe we just disallow it since it would become a massive foot gun otherwise.

> Do we need a fast_loop where non-editor, Lua-only processing is done? 

This probably surpasses my knowledge of how the event loop works, but are you suggesting we create another loop which uv binds to in fast-callbacks? Could that even work?

IMO introducing a secondary event loop would be the wrong way to go. 

if we want to allow "sync style" code inside callback (i e a `vim.system` which waits and returns, instead of taking yet another callback), we need to use something based on co-routines, so the callback can be suspended and the top-level event loop resumed.

> I don't see how we can run the uv loop when we are in a fast callback,

Another (half-baked, probably wrong) idea is for the fast callback to "re-schedule itself on the main loop". But suspend-and-resume as @bfredl mentioned, sounds much better.

Yes I agree, however given how `lua_resume` and `lua_yield` are needed to be used, I think that would require a lot of effort to get this to work. 

It may just to easier to disallow `vim.wait` in fast events. It's not something we test and hasn't been an issue until now.

For stuff like timers, I don't see any benefit to running the callbacks in fast events and users should just wrap the callbacks with `vim.schedule_wrap()`. tbh I think this is true for 99% for fast callbacks. It is only things like `uv_idle_t`, `uv_prepare_t` objects that benefit from using fast callbacks.

> It may just to easier to disallow `vim.wait` in fast events.

Throwing an error is fine for now, because it's a 2-way door: we can always relax it in the future.
can we also assert the error message?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2769,6 +2769,19 @@ describe('lua stdlib', function()
         eq({'notification', 'wait', {-2}}, next_msg(500))
       end)
     end)
+
+    it('should not run in fast callbacks #26122', function()
+      exec_lua([[
+        vim.uv.new_timer():start(0, 100, function()
+          local count = 0
+          vim.wait(100, function()
+            count = count + 1
+            return count == 10
+          end, 100)
+        end)
+      ]])
+      assert_alive()

comment_data.body:
Not easily since the error happens in a luv callback which doesn't get sent back over RPC to busted.

In Gitsigns testsuite I've solved this by overriding `error()` to send back an error event: https://github.com/lewis6991/gitsigns.nvim/blob/main/test/helpers.lua#L339-L342
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2769,6 +2769,19 @@ describe('lua stdlib', function()
         eq({'notification', 'wait', {-2}}, next_msg(500))
       end)
     end)
+
+    it('should not run in fast callbacks #26122', function()
+      exec_lua([[
+        vim.uv.new_timer():start(0, 100, function()
+          local count = 0
+          vim.wait(100, function()
+            count = count + 1
+            return count == 10
+          end, 100)
+        end)
+      ]])
+      assert_alive()

comment_regular_data.body: I've pivoted this PR to just disallow `vim.wait` in api-fast, however I've raised https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26198 to experiment with the suspend and resume idea.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lua): do not allow `vim.wait()` in fast callbacks
